results.title: Blackberry subway jam
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Douglas MacDonald, Eunice Macaulay and Robert Doucet
results.brief_description: Animated version of the popular children’s story by Robert Munsch is about a young boy with a major problem: his apartment has become a subway station but his mother doesn’t believe him and blames him for the commuters’ mess. Jonathan takes his problem to City Hall and gets his first look at what bureaucratic bungling is all about. Munsch’s story is entitled Jonathan Cleaned Up—Then He Heard a Sound. Music by Alex Pauk. Voice and narration by Hannah Goodheart.

results.title: Blackadder: The foretelling
results.brief_description: Three episodes, starring Rowan Atkinson as the Black Adder. “The Foretelling” - from out of the swirling mists of the dark ages comes a lone horseman cursed from youth by a deformed haircut and sporting a particularly evil pair of tights. “The Archbishop” - the landscape is littered with the dead Archbishops of Canterbury. Edmund’s cunning plan is to get his deadliest rival appointed to the vacancy, but before long Archbishop Edmund the Reluctant finds life a tricky thing to hold on to. “Born to be King” - treachery, murder and Morris-dancing break out in all their full horror when an orange faced stranger arrives at court.

results.title: Blackadder: back & forth
results.brief_description: December 31st, 1999, and everyone has gathered at Blackadder’s for millennium celebrations. There is money to be made, $10,000 in fact, when Blackadder claims he can bring back items from the past using a time machine developed by Baldrick. It will be the best New Year’s Eve prank ever. Complications arise when they discover the time machine actually works, there’s something lacking in the navigation department, and they have the opportunity to change history. In their travels Blackadder and Baldrick encounter Shakespeare (Colin Firth), Robin Hood (Rik Mayall) and Maid Marion (Kate Moss), Napoleon, Roman Centurions and Queen Elizabeth I. Also included on the tape are ‘Baldrick’s video diary’ and a behind the scenes look at the production of the film, ‘A Blackadder in the making’ (directed by Anthony Palmer). This includes interviews with cast and crew members including Richard Curtis, Rowan Atkinson, Paul Weiland, Stephen Fry, Hugh Laurie, Miranda Richardson and Patsy Byrne who provide insights into character and series developed.

results.title: Blackadder the third. - [Vol. 2].
results.brief_description: With anarchists lurking, Blackadder suggests Prince George make a sympathetic speech towards the proletariat. They hire two actors to help with public speaking, until Baldrick uncovers what appears to be a plot to murder the Prince. It is really a combination of “Sense and Senility” as Blackadder tries to win the day. Broke as usual, Prince George must supplement his income by marrying a wealthy woman. In “Amy and amiability” he tries to do just that, however it is Blackadder’s attempt at becoming a highwayman which reaps monetry rewards. When Prince George is not engaged in illicit liasons with the Duke of Wellington’s neices, he is being challenged to a duel by the same gentleman. Blackadder, taking advantage of his look-alike cousin McAdder, “the most dangerous man to wear a skirt in Europe”, offers to take the Prince’s place.

results.title: Blackadder the third. - [Vol. 1].
results.brief_description: The Blackadder Chronicles continue into the golden age of wealth, power and discovery but not for Edmund Blackadder Esquire. Rowan Atkinson is Blackadder, the permanently exasperated and scheming butler. Tony Robinson is Baldrick, the unimaginably stupid manservant and Hugh Laurie is His Royal Highness, a foppish fool. The three hilarious episodes are “Dish and dishonesty”: When the new Prime Minister, Pitt the Younger, threatens to bankrupt the Prince Regent, Blackadder, seeing his livelihood threatened springs into action. The fate and fortune of the Blackadder camp rest on the newly elected member for Parliament, Baldrick. “Ink and incapability”: Prince George is approached by Dr. Johnson with a view to patronising his new dictionary. Blackadder is unimpressed until Johnson’s enthusiasm for a novel by a “Gertrude Perkins” becomes clear. In the interim what has Baldrick done with the only copy of the dictionary? “Nob and nobility”: Following the French Revolution everybody in England, except Blackadder, has lost their heads over things French and the heroic Scarlet Pimpernel. However, Blackadder and the Pimpernel’s paths soon cross.

results.title: Blackadder II. - Parte the seconde.
results.brief_description: Written by Ben Elton and Richard Curtis. The scene is England 1586-1603, Lord Edmund Blackadder swaggers back with a big head and a small beard, constantly trying to curry favour with the mad Queen Bess. Accompanied by a small rabble of beruffed riff-raff - bottom-breath Baldrick and pea-brained Percy - the serpentine Lord Blackadder lowers the tone of England’s Golden Age. “Money”, finds Blackadder in deep to the baby-eating Bishop of Bath and Wells, (guest star Ronald Lacey). Can he raise the cash to pay back the loan and manage to avoid having the red hot poker torture? “Beer”, with Miriam Margoyles as Lady Whiteadder, sees Blackadder frantically trying to impress his puritan aunt, while trying to live up to his macho image - an inheritance hangs in the balance! “Chains”, with Hugh Laurie as Ludwig, an evil German master of disguise captures Blackadder and Cardinal Melchett, (Stephen Fry), and is determined to hold them for ransom, the only problem is that Queen Bess has decided she will no longer pay ransom demands - two lives hang in the balance!

results.title: Blackadder II. - Parte the firste.
results.brief_description: England 1558-1603. The filthy genes of the Blackadder dynasty bubble to the surface of the melting pot of history as Lord Edmund, arrogant peer-about-town, swaggers with a big head and small beard in search of grace and favour from stark raving mad Queen Bess (Miranda Richardson). Blackadder is hearing “Bells” and police sirens as he falls in love with his manservant Bob, who is not all he seems to be! Guest stars Rik Mayall as the dashing Lord Flashheart. Blackadder is appointed Minister in charge of Religious Genocide and Lord High Executioner, where his time saving measures cause more than a few people to lose their “Head”. Blackadder sets off unwillingly to seek out a new “Potato” and to boldly go where Sir Walter Raleigh has been before. Written by Ben Elton.

results.title: Blackadder goes forth. - Volume 2.
results.brief_description: The Western Front 1917: Captain Blackadder joins the British Army and has to take orders from two homicidal maniacs - one called the Charge of the Light Brigade ‘a victory for common sense’, and the other called Darling. “Private Plane” sees the German machine guns in front, British firing squads behind - the only way out is to tiddly-up-up! Guest starring Rik Mayall and Ade Edmonson as two dashing arch-rivals. “General Hospital”, guest stars Miranda Richardson as a Florence Nightingale-type ordered to find a spy in a military hospital. Blackadder spots a man with a strong German accent, a beautiful nurse and a chance for three weeks in bed. “Goodbyeee” guest stars Geoffrey Palmer is a megalomaniacal Field Marshall when the big push is finally looming and with the help of two pencils and a pair of underpants, Blackadder goes stir-fry crazy!
